proposals.reasoning: I know I’m good as Charlie, and there’s a broad table preference for including Diana plus exactly one of Alice/Bob, with slightly more suspicion aimed at Alice so I’m choosing Bob. This team matches the general consensus structure (one of Alice/Bob, Diana, and one of Charlie/Eve), avoids giving early control to both loud voices at once, and includes myself so I can directly influence and observe the first mission while keeping risk reasonably distributed.

votes.comment: I’d rather start with a team that includes me or at least someone I feel more confident reading; this feels a bit too tailored to table consensus instead of genuine trust.

Fits the table’s preferred structure (one of Alice/Bob plus Diana and a quieter player), keeps both early loud voices off the same team, and there’s no concrete reason yet to distrust any of these three more than the alternatives.

Team matches the broad consensus structure (one of Alice/Bob, Diana, and one of Charlie/Eve) and avoids stacking both early loud voices; as a good player on it myself, this is a reasonable info-gathering first mission.
This matches the broadly preferred structure (Diana + exactly one of Alice/Bob + Charlie/Eve), avoids pairing both loud voices, and as good I’m okay taking limited risk on Mission 1 for info.
Fits the consensus structure (one of Alice/Bob, Diana, and one of Eve/Charlie). No strong reason yet to block an info-rich first mission.
Fits the broadly preferred structure (exactly one of Alice/Bob plus Diana plus Charlie/Eve), no strong red flags yet, and we need early info.
Fits the broadly agreed structure (exactly one of Alice/Bob plus Diana and a quieter player), and Mission 1 is low-risk and good for gathering info.
This matches the structure I argued for earlier (one of Alice/Bob, plus Diana, plus Charlie/Eve), so rejecting now would be inconsistent and suspicious.
This isn’t the structure I preferred—I wanted Diana plus Alice or Eve, and leaving both Alice and Eve off feels like we’re narrowing early info too much.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d like a mix of people who’ve talked a bit but haven’t been overly pushy yet—something like Alice, Bob, and Diana feels reasonably safe. I’m a bit wary of piling on folks who are already trying too hard to steer the table this early.

I’m a little hesitant to lock you in on the very first team, Alice—feels safer to get a broader spread of info early—so I’d rather see something like Bob, Diana, and maybe Charlie or Eve instead. That way we’re not just trusting the first proposer by default.

I’m fine being considered, but I’d rather avoid both Alice and Bob on the very first team so we’re not giving early control to the two main voices—something like Charlie, Diana, and Eve feels like a cleaner info-gathering start.

I’d like to be on the first team with a mix of one vocal player and one quieter one—something like Bob, Diana, and Eve or Alice, Diana, and Charlie—so we’re spreading risk without letting any single pair control the early game.

I like starting with Diana plus two of the quieter folks—something like Diana, Charlie, and me—or if we want Bob’s voice in the mix, then Bob, Diana, and me feels better than auto-locking Alice on the very first team.

I’d like to keep exactly one of Alice/Bob on the first team plus Diana, and then fill the third slot with someone who hasn’t pushed a strong agenda yet—Eve or Charlie both fit that better than doubling up on the early loud voices.

I’d really prefer we don’t exclude both Alice and Bob from the first team—having exactly one of them plus Diana and either Eve or Charlie feels like a good balance of info without handing too much control to any single pair.

I’d rather start with exactly one of Alice/Bob plus Diana and then either Eve or Charlie, and right now I’m a bit more wary of Alice’s early framing than Bob’s. That gives us a solid mix of voices without handing too much control to the people who set the tone from the very start.
I’d like to see Diana on the first team for sure, and between the loud voices I slightly prefer starting with Alice plus someone like Eve so we’re not over‑indexing on Bob this early.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Bob, Charlie, and me (Diana) succeeded with 0 fails, so while that doesn’t confirm anyone as good, it’s the only data we have. The table talk has broadly converged on reusing two members from that first team and adding two new players from Eve/Frank/Grace/Iris for better information spread. I’m choosing Bob and myself as the carry-overs because the majority of players currently lean toward that pair over Charlie, and then adding Eve and Frank because both have engaged with the plan, are not yet tested, and including them together gives us strong informational value from this mission’s result while still anchoring the team around the only clean mission we’ve seen so far.

votes.comment: I’m not on the team and all four picks are untested or lightly tested; if this passes and succeeds, it gives us very little to work with and risks locking in a strong-looking core too early.
No known evil players (Alice, Henry) are on it; good early info team anchored on the only clean mission so far.
Clean first mission, broad consensus on using Bob+Diana plus two untested players; good info gain even if there’s some risk.
This follows the table’s consensus of reusing two from the clean mission and adding two untested players, giving good info while anchoring on the only successful team so far.
Includes two from a clean mission plus me, and only one completely untested player beyond that; good info gain with reasonable risk at this stage.
Team follows the broadly agreed plan of reusing 2 from the clean mission plus 2 new players, giving good info while still anchored on the only successful team so far.
Fits the table’s consensus of 2 from the clean team plus 2 new; good early info and includes Bob, who might be Merlin, without looking suspiciously optimized.

I wanted a Bob+Diana core but with Iris and one of Eve/Frank to balance info and table presence; putting both Eve and Frank together while excluding Iris feels like it overloads the team with untested players in the same group.
I still prefer a Bob + Diana core but would rather not have both Eve and Frank together; I’d like a mix that includes me or Grace instead for better info spread.

discussion.content: Mission 1 being clean doesn’t clear everyone on it, but it does make me a bit more comfortable with Bob and Diana in particular; I’d like at least one of them on the next team, plus a mix from outside that first mission so we get more info.

I’m fine reusing at least one from the first mission, but I’d rather not stack it with too many new unknowns all at once. Something like one of Charlie/Diana plus two from Eve/Frank/Grace/Iris (and avoiding putting both of the really quiet players together) feels like a safer way to build info.

Given mission 1 was clean, I’d like to keep two of Bob/Diana/myself on the team and then add two from Eve/Frank/Grace/Iris so we’re spreading risk but still building off the only trustworthy data we have. I lean toward something like Bob, Diana, Eve, and Frank unless someone has a strong read against that.

I like keeping two from the first mission, and I’m obviously happy to go again; Bob feels a bit safer than Charlie to me right now, so I’d lean toward something like Bob, me, and then two from Eve/Frank/Grace/Iris rather than all three of us from mission 1.
I’m on board with the “two from mission 1 plus two new” idea, and I’d prefer Bob and Diana over Charlie right now, with me and one of Frank/Grace/Iris to widen the info we get.

I’m good sticking with the “two from mission 1 plus two new” plan, and I slightly prefer Bob and Diana over Charlie right now, so I’d like to see something like Bob, Diana, me, and one of Grace/Iris on this team.

I like the “two from mission 1 plus two new” plan as well, and I’m leaning Bob+Diana as the carry-overs, with myself and one of Eve/Frank/Iris to spread info without overloading the team with total unknowns.

I’m okay with the “two from mission 1 plus two new” approach, and I’d lean Bob and Diana as the carry-overs with Iris and one of Eve/Frank to widen the info we get without putting too many total unknowns together.

I’m fine with the “Bob + Diana + two new” consensus, and I’d slightly prefer adding myself and one of Eve/Frank so we get a mix of quieter and more vocal players while still building off the only clean mission we’ve seen.

proposals.reasoning: We keep exactly one of the proven core (Diana, who has been on both successful missions) while adding myself (Eve, who was on the clean second mission) plus two fresh players (Grace and Iris) that many people wanted to test. If this team succeeds, it strongly clears Diana, me, Grace, and Iris and gives us a very solid block of trusted players for later missions. If it fails, we know the spy (or spies) must be within {Diana, Grace, Iris}, since I know I’m good, which gives us sharply focused information without just repeating previous team compositions.

votes.comment: Fits the ‘exactly one of Bob/Diana’ plan, keeps Eve from a clean mission, and tests two new players for better info.
Keeps a proven core while testing two new players and stays consistent with how the clean teams have looked so far.

We’re 2–0 and should prioritize a high-probability win over info. This team pulls two members from the largely untested group (Grace, Iris), where it’s likely most of the spies are, instead of leaning more on the proven core. I’d prefer a team using more of {Bob, Charlie, Diana, Eve, Frank} and at most one true newcomer.
I know I’m good, Eve was on a clean mission, and this tests Grace and Iris while keeping exactly one of the proven core, giving strong info either way.
Good info team with exactly one of Bob/Diana, includes me plus two new players; at 2-0 up this is a reasonable balance of safety and information.
Team fits the ‘exactly one of Bob/Diana plus new faces’ plan I supported earlier, keeps part of the proven core, and gives strong info either way without looking obviously worse than any alternative.
Fits the consensus plan of exactly one of Bob/Diana plus new faces; good mix of prior success (Diana, Eve) and info gain (me, Iris).
This matches the kind of team I said I wanted (Diana + Grace + Iris + one of Eve/Frank), so approving keeps my story consistent while adding fresh info.
I like the exactly-one-of-Bob/Diana structure plus adding two newer faces; it fits the info-gathering plan the table’s been pushing.

discussion.content: Both quests being clean with Bob and Diana on every team is a bit too convenient, so I’d like to see at least one of them sit out this time and mix in people like me and Grace to actually get new info.

Given we’ve had two clean missions with Bob and Diana, I’d be hesitant to bench both of them at once. I’d prefer a team that keeps at least one of those proven picks and mixes in someone like Grace or Iris rather than rebuilding around totally new people.

I’m okay keeping exactly one of Bob or Diana for info, but I really want to add at least one fresh face like Grace or Iris so we’re not just rereading the same setup. Right now I’m leaning toward a team like Bob/Diana + me + Grace.

I really don’t think it makes sense to bench both of the people who’ve been on every successful mission so far, so I’d like to stay on and then add someone like Grace or Iris while we test whether Bob or Charlie is actually as safe as they look.

Given two clean missions, I’m inclined to trust at least some of that core, but for info I’d like a team with exactly one of Bob/Diana plus a couple of us who’ve already passed (like me or Frank) and then a new face like Grace or Iris. That way, if it fails, we can actually narrow down where the problem is instead of just rerunning the same group.

I like the “exactly one of Bob/Diana” idea, and I’d lean toward a team like Diana + me + Grace + Iris so we’re keeping some of the proven core while actually testing new people. If that team fails, we get a really clear pool to look at without throwing away all the info we’ve built so far.

I’m on board with the “exactly one of Bob/Diana” idea, and I’d prefer something like Diana + Eve/Frank + me + Iris so we’re combining a bit of the proven core with fresh info instead of just rerunning the same group.

I like the “exactly one of Bob/Diana” approach too, and I’d lean toward something like Diana + Grace + Iris + one of Eve/Frank so we’re mixing the proven core with a couple of newer faces. Keeping Bob off this one gives us cleaner info if it does go wrong instead of just repeating the same pattern.
I like the “exactly one of Bob/Diana” idea too, and I’d be happiest with something like Diana + Grace + Henry + me so we keep a proven core while actually testing a couple of newer faces.

proposals.reasoning: Missions 1 and 2 were both clean and the overlapping core there is Bob, Charlie, Diana, and Frank, giving us the strongest historically reliable block. Mission 3’s only fail came from the Diana/Eve/Grace/Iris group, so we avoid stacking that group by including only Diana from that mission, who also has two prior clean missions. Alice is added as the fifth member because she is outside the failed cluster and widely trusted in discussion, giving us a team that maximizes use of proven players while minimizing overlap with the failed Mission 3 lineup.

votes.comment: Only one suspected spy at most on this team; too clean and likely to succeed for good
This team still includes at least one highly suspicious player; with the score at 2–1 we should aim for a lineup with fewer red flags.
Best use of the proven core from Missions 1 and 2 while limiting the suspicious Mission 3 block to only Diana; statistically our safest shot to win here.
I know I’m good, so the Mission 3 fail must be from Eve/Grace/Iris. This team includes only me from that mission plus the clean core from Missions 1 and 2, making it our safest option.

I know I’m good, so the Mission 3 fail must come from {Diana, Grace, Iris}. That makes Diana strictly more suspicious than Henry. A safer team would use only Alice/Bob/Charlie/Frank/Henry and exclude the entire Mission 3 suspect block, rather than keeping Diana on.

This team still includes Diana, the only overlap between the clean missions and the failed Mission 3, when we could field a fully 'clean' team like Alice/Bob/Charlie/Frank/Henry that has zero members from the failed lineup (D/E/Grace/Iris). With a safer alternative available, I don’t want to risk including anyone from the known-failed cluster here.
Strong core from two clean missions, only one member from the failed mission 3, and mission 4 needs two fails to go down—this lineup is as safe and informative as we can get.
Strong overlap with the two clean missions and only one member from the failed Mission 3 team; best odds based on current info.
Two known-to-me evils on the team, strong chance to sabotage while the group feels ‘safe’ with the core from earlier clean missions.

discussion.content: Given Mission 3 was the only fail, I think we should lean heavily on people from the first two clean missions—Bob, Charlie, Frank—and add myself plus at most one person from that last team (Diana/Eve/Grace/Iris) so we’re not repeating the whole suspicious block.

I like the idea of leaning on the proven groups, but I’d be most comfortable with something like Bob/Charlie/Diana/Frank plus one of Eve/Grace/Iris, rather than bringing in both multiple people from the failed team and someone who hasn’t been tested at all yet. That keeps a solid core from the two clean missions while limiting overlap with the last one.

I’m broadly on board with anchoring around Bob, Frank, and myself, but for the other two slots I’d rather take Alice plus just one from the failed mission—probably Diana over Eve given her track record across Missions 1–3.

Given Missions 1 and 2 were both clean with Bob, Charlie, Frank, and me, I’m very happy with a core of us four plus Alice, and I’d strongly prefer we avoid stacking in more than one person from the failed Mission 3 (Eve/Grace/Iris).

I get that Mission 3 makes me look bad, so I’m fine sitting out this round if it helps, but I’d much rather see a team like Bob/Charlie/Diana/Frank plus exactly one of me/Grace/Iris than start pulling in too many untested combos.

I’m good keeping a tight core of Bob/Charlie/me plus Alice, with just one person from the failed team—Diana makes the most sense given Missions 1 and 2, but if that team ever fails we have to look very hard at her.

I’m happy to sit this one out given the Mission 3 fail, and I like a team of Bob/Charlie/Frank plus Alice and Diana as our best balance of prior clean missions and minimized overlap with the last team.

Given Mission 3 is our only data point with a fail and it exclusively involved Diana/Eve/Grace/Iris, I’m most comfortable with the consensus of Bob/Charlie/Frank plus Alice and Diana, and I’d really rather not see more than one person from that failed team on this mission. Keeping Iris/Eve/Grace off together minimizes the chance we accidentally stack spies here.

I get why everyone likes the Bob/Charlie/Frank core, but if we’re this close to losing I’d really rather not lock in the exact same block every time—I'd prefer we work in at least one of Alice/Henry/Iris so we aren’t blindly trusting an untested cluster.

proposals.reasoning: We need to hard-exclude the most suspicious overlaps on the two failed missions. Diana is the only player on both failed teams (missions 3 and 4), so I am keeping her off entirely. Iris only appears on the failed mission 3 and is being heavily associated with that fail in the table talk, so I prefer to avoid her as well rather than stake the last mission on her alignment. Charlie and Frank were both on the failed mission 4, and Frank led that team, so I’d rather not bring either of them when we have other viable options. Bob is the closest thing to a consensus anchor and has been on both successful missions, so I’m including him. Alice’s suggested structure (Bob + Alice + Grace + Henry + one of Eve/Frank) is consistent with excluding the main suspects and fits the mission history, and her perspective lines up well with treating Diana as the common spy, so I’m following that frame and including Alice. Between Eve and Frank, I’m choosing Eve because Frank both proposed and rode the last failed team, which is riskier than Eve’s involvement in a single fail alongside Diana. Rounding out with Henry and myself avoids stacking too many of the previously failing combinations together, while still staying close to the majority’s preference for building around Bob and excluding Diana.

votes.comment: This team excludes the main overlapping suspects from the failed missions and keeps Diana and Iris off, while anchoring around Bob and a clean-looking Eve. I’m comfortable testing this mix for the final mission.
Too many untested players (Alice, Grace, Henry) together on the deciding mission, and it ignores cleaner options built around Bob plus multiple players from the successful teams.

I know I’m good and this team leaves me off while still including multiple players from the failed missions (Alice, Bob, Eve, Grace) with no strong clearing info; I’d rather push for a lineup that includes me and avoids stacking so many from the previous fails.

Excludes Diana (only overlap of both fails), Iris (heavily tied to the mission 3 fail), and the risky Charlie/Frank combo from mission 4. Anchors on Bob (on both successes) with Eve plus two untested players, which fits the mission history better than most alternatives.
Team still includes Alice, who was on the failed mission 4 and is a plausible partner with Diana; I’d prefer swapping Alice for someone cleaner like Frank or Iris while keeping Diana off entirely.

Bob and Eve are solid, but this team adds three relatively untested/suspect players (Alice, Grace, Henry) while leaving off Frank, who looks good from mission 2 if we treat Diana as the common spy on both fails. I’d rather anchor around Bob, Eve, and Frank and only add two of the less-tested players.
Alice is more likely Merlin than Bob based on her consistent push to exclude Diana and Iris, and this team matches her preferred structure while hard-excluding the main suspect (Diana).
This matches the structure I argued for earlier: Bob as anchor, Diana and Iris excluded, with Eve plus a mix of relatively untested players rather than re‑stacking the mission 4 combo.
This keeps Diana off, avoids the riskiest overlaps from the failed teams, and still anchors around Bob with a solid-looking mix that fits the mission history.

discussion.content: Given both failed missions had Diana on them and Mission 3 had Iris on the only other fail, I’d really like a team that avoids both of them—something like Bob, Grace, Henry, myself, and one of Eve/Frank feels a lot safer right now.

I’m not convinced cutting both Diana and Iris is justified when Diana’s been on two clean missions and we’ve never actually tested Alice or Henry yet. I’d feel safer with something like Bob, Charlie, Diana, Eve, and Frank (or swapping in Grace for one of Eve/Frank) rather than stacking the team with untested players.

Diana’s the only player on both failed missions, so I really don’t want her on this team; if we assume she’s the spy on those, Iris actually looks cleaner, and I’d be happiest with something like Bob, Charlie, Eve, Frank, and one of Grace/Henry.

From my seat, the only thing we know for sure is that the two fails drew their spies from disjoint groups around me, so I’m most comfortable locking in Bob plus some combination of Eve/Frank, and being very cautious about stacking too many of {Alice, Charlie, Grace, Iris} on this last team.

Given the mission 3/4 overlaps, Diana has to be the spy there, which means Alice, Bob, Charlie, and Frank are all cleared from that fail — I’d strongly back a team of Alice, Bob, Charlie, Frank, and myself with Diana hard-excluded.

From the mission patterns, I’m happiest assuming Diana is the common spy and that Bob and Eve are clean from the all‑good mission 2, so I’d like a team of Bob, Eve, me, Henry, and one of Grace/Iris (leaning Grace). I really don’t want Diana back on the team, and I’m wary of putting both Alice and Charlie on together after mission 4.

I really don’t want Diana back on after being the only common factor on both fails, and I think Bob is the safest lock we’ve got. From there I’d much rather see a mix like Bob plus some combination of Alice/Charlie/Eve/Frank with maybe me or Henry, but not stacking too many of the untested people together.

I’m with the folks who want Diana hard‑off this team, and I think Bob is our safest anchor with Eve and Frank both looking pretty good from the mission history. From there I’d pick two of Grace/Henry/Iris rather than stacking both Alice and Charlie again, since that combo is exactly what burned us on mission 4.

I’m fully on board with keeping Diana off this one and anchoring around Bob, with Eve and Frank looking solid from the history, and then rounding it out with two of Grace/Henry/Iris. If we want to minimize risk, I’d lean Bob, Eve, Frank, Henry, and me.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of evil by staying low-key early and helping keep suspicion off Henry and Iris until the later missions, which set up a strong endgame where good struggled to trust their own reads. I could improve by crafting a clearer, more believable Merlin candidate persona to more strongly mislead Grace-as-Percival, since my Morgana presence didn’t seem to fully hijack their trust.

player_observations.Bob: You played a very subtle Merlin, staying mostly quiet and non-confrontational, which kept you alive and believable without drawing the assassin’s eye too early.
player_observations.Charlie: You seemed to rely heavily on mission history rather than strong vocal reads, which made your accusations feel cautious and occasionally late to form.
player_observations.Diana: You projected a very ‘solid villager’ vibe, consistently logical and calm, but you didn’t hard-push your suspicions, which let evil slip through a couple of critical team votes.
player_observations.Eve: You played quite transparently good, but your trust calibration felt shaky at times, which evil leveraged when you supported some mixed teams without fully locking in who you distrusted.
player_observations.Frank: You were willing to put bold teams on the table, but your explanations sometimes lagged behind your choices, which made you look a bit erratic and easier to frame as suspicious.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival you were actively hunting for Merlin, but you seemed torn between multiple candidates and never fully committed, which weakened good’s ability to rally around a trusted core.
player_observations.Henry: You stayed well-camouflaged as assassin, not overreaching for control and letting others drive the table talk, which made your eventual assassination decision more informed and less pressured.
player_observations.Iris: You played Mordred with a very understated style, avoiding being the center of attention while still nudging team selections just enough to keep evil represented on key missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified that evil influence was concentrated around Alice, Henry, and Iris, but I didn’t communicate that information clearly or consistently enough through my voting and team preferences, which made it hard for good players to read me. I also played too cautiously in the late game, trying to avoid being obviously Merlin rather than aggressively steering the team away from the final losing composition.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-drama game; she avoided early mission fails and blended into standard good-team logic, which made her Morgana signal fairly subtle until the later missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie’s behavior was relatively straightforward and trusting, often going along with consensus, which made him look quite genuinely good but also a bit easy to influence.
player_observations.Diana: Consistent, reasonable mission choices and low-variance behavior made Diana read clearly good; she avoided over-assertiveness and created a stable core for the good team to rally around, even if we didn’t fully capitalize on it.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s fail on Mission 3 (from my perspective) was largely a framing issue from team composition rather than her own behavior; her table talk and voting patterns stayed pretty aligned with a sincere good player trying to puzzle things out.
player_observations.Frank: Frank’s leadership on Mission 4 was cautious but not strongly theory-driven; the resulting fail suggested he either misread the table or was overly trusting of players who had flown under the radar.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, Grace was clearly trying to parse the Merlin/Morgana signals, but she seemed to give Alice too much benefit of the doubt and didn’t push hard enough for alternative late-game teams once suspicion should have shifted.
player_observations.Henry: Henry stayed relatively quiet and opportunistic, stepping into critical spots (especially around the final mission) without drawing much suspicion, which is strong assassin positioning for the endgame.
player_observations.Iris: Iris played Mordred very subtly, benefiting from being off some early teams and not being heavily associated with obvious fails, making her a persistent but low-visibility threat that was hard for the table to lock onto.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the early mission successes too much and didn’t push hard enough on resolving the contradictions around Mission 3, which let evil stay comfortably hidden. Next time I should be more vocal about forcing clear info from team compositions and voting patterns, especially questioning why I kept being included or excluded and what that implied about others’ reads.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled and low-friction game; blended into the background just enough that her presence on later, failing teams didn’t trigger strong pushback.
player_observations.Bob: Came across very confident and authoritative in team discussions, which fit a Merlin-like info game but also made it hard to distinguish between genuine knowledge and strong town-posturing.
player_observations.Diana: Seemed consistently cooperative and reasonable, and their willingness to repeat team structures made them look reliably good, which helped evil hide behind that stability.
player_observations.Eve: Their leadership on the failing Mission 3 looked cautious rather than suspicious, which made that mission’s single fail more confusing and less clearly attributable.
player_observations.Frank: As a leader on Mission 4, chose a broadly ‘safe-looking’ team that still contained evil, suggesting they were heavily weighting social trust and early success over hard logical elimination.
player_observations.Grace: Played assertively and took strong stances, especially in the late game, which created a lot of trust around them and allowed the final team to go through despite being heavily compromised.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed relatively under the radar for much of the game, only becoming sharply impactful with the final mission fail and endgame position, which is a very effective assassin-style approach.
player_observations.Iris: Maintained a low but steady presence, rarely drawing direct suspicion; their positioning on the failing Mission 3 was subtle enough that it didn’t generate the pressure it probably should have.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted too broadly after the first two clean missions and didn’t push hard enough to narrow down who was likely evil before the late-game critical teams. I also relied too much on table consensus instead of forcing people to justify their reads, which let evil hide comfortably.

player_observations.Alice: Played very under-the-radar Morgana, mixing occasional strong opinions with stretches of quiet, which helped her slip into late-game teams without much resistance.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he tried to steer away from some evil picks but stayed cautious enough that his reads often looked like normal good-guy uncertainty, which unfortunately left the table without strong direction.
player_observations.Charlie: Very straightforward and consistent, voting and talking in a way that made him feel reliably good but also not very assertive in shaping where suspicion should go.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as genuinely confused and open, which fit a good role but also didn’t strongly challenge risky team comps when it mattered.
player_observations.Frank: As a good leader on Mission 4, he tried to balance trust and information-gathering but ended up assembling a mixed team that gave evil exactly the window they needed.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she was clearly trying to protect who she thought was Merlin, but her uncertainty between Merlin/Morgana created some hesitation and may have funneled trust toward the wrong person at key moments.
player_observations.Henry: Played Assassin with a confident, slightly aggressive style that didn’t draw too much suspicion, and he benefited from the general confusion about Merlin’s identity at the end.
player_observations.Iris: Mordred stayed very well camouflaged, blending into the midpack of suspicion and rarely being the focal point of discussion, which made her inclusion on failing teams feel plausible rather than alarming.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed fairly consistent with my voting and team choices, which helped maintain a generally good-aligned image and avoided creating chaos. However, I should have pressed harder on the implications of Mission 3’s single fail and then re-evaluated trust in Alice going into Mission 4 and 5, as I didn’t narrow down the evil team quickly enough.

player_observations.Alice: Played very conservatively early, avoiding suspicion by not appearing on failing teams until late; used her presence on the big 5-player Mission 4 and 5 to deliver decisive fails while still blending into the logic of common team constructions.
player_observations.Bob: Balanced information and subtlety well as Merlin, joining critical missions (like Mission 4) without becoming an obvious focal point of suspicion; seemed to nudge trust patterns without overtly hard-pushing accusations.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a straightforward, low-drama good style, accepting early team proposals and not overcomplicating the read landscape; didn’t generate much suspicion but also didn’t strongly steer the table away from evil.
player_observations.Diana: Looked very towny by leading a successful Mission 2 and then appearing again on my Mission 3 team that only had a single fail; projected reliability, which made it easier for evil to hide alongside her.
player_observations.Frank: As a leader on the crucial 5-player Mission 4, built a team that felt reasonably logical but unfortunately centered around existing trust patterns that included Alice; seemed to prefer constructing broadly acceptable teams rather than hard-pushing niche reads.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, appeared to trust Bob strongly enough to keep him in contention but not so strongly that it screamed role-knowledge; on the final mission, accepted a risky mix (including Alice and Henry) that looked like a compromise between social reads and table pressure.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed under the radar most of the game, then capitalized late by joining the final mission and dropping a fail alongside Alice; generally avoided moves that would have made him a standout suspect before Mission 5.
player_observations.Iris: Took advantage of being on my Mission 3 team to slip in a single fail that created ambiguity without overexposing herself; her presence there created confusion between multiple possible suspects and set up later evil wins.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and avoided raising suspicion, which helped keep trust in me high throughout the game. However, I didn’t push hard enough on deduction or publicly challenge shaky assumptions about who was evil, especially after Mission 3 failed, and I should have been more vocal in narrowing down evil candidates.

player_observations.Alice: Very effective at blending into the middle of the trust spectrum; she avoided being too central early, then slipped onto key late missions as Morgana without drawing heavy heat.
player_observations.Bob: Played a subtle, cautious Merlin—gave helpful but not overtly strong steers, which protected his identity but also made it harder for the rest of us to confidently follow his reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Played straightforward and low-drama, which made them seem reliably good but also meant they didn’t strongly direct the table when suspicions were fragmented.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as solidly trustworthy, taking part in 2 successful missions and not overtalking her innocence, which helped her avoid suspicion even after being on the failed Mission 3.
player_observations.Eve: Accepted being on some high-risk teams and didn’t overdefend herself after Mission 3, which paradoxically made her seem more good; her calmness under suspicion was a strength.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she clearly tried to leverage information to shape Mission 5, but her final team choices showed how convincingly the evil pair had confused Merlin/Morgana signals.
player_observations.Henry: Played a bold late-game evil, confidently stepping onto the final mission and coordinating the decisive double fail, showing strong timing and awareness of table reads.
player_observations.Iris: Stayed in the background for much of the game, letting others take the social spotlight; this quiet Mordred style made it hard for good to justify excluding her from consideration without strong evidence.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly treated Bob and Alice as the Merlin/Morgana pair but didn’t do enough to resolve which was which before the later missions, and I let my uncertainty push a risky Mission 5 team. I need to be more vocal earlier about my Merlin-read logic and press harder on consistency checks after each mission result, especially once Mission 3 failed.

player_observations.Alice: Sold the Merlin impression well as Morgana and stayed consistently central to the discussion without overreaching, which helped her remain plausible as a key good role.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-key Merlin, giving gentle nudges rather than hard pushes, which was good for staying hidden but made it harder for me as Percival to distinguish him clearly from Morgana.
player_observations.Charlie: Played straightforwardly and supported reasonable early teams, which helped M1 succeed but also made him blend into the background a bit as a generally trusted good.
player_observations.Diana: Came off as solidly good, especially with her leadership on M2 succeeding cleanly, but didn’t strongly challenge the later suspicious team compositions.
player_observations.Eve: Seemed good and consistent most of the game, and taking the blame risk on M3 leadership made her look even more genuine after only a single fail appeared.
player_observations.Frank: As a good player, his M4 leadership ending in a single fail hurt, and he didn’t fully capitalize on that result to press hard on the evil candidates afterward.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very quiet but deadly evil game, staying off most early suspicion and then fitting smoothly onto the final doomed team as Assassin.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, stayed comfortably under the radar and allowed other players to take center stage, which helped evil avoid focused scrutiny even after multiple fails appeared.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well hidden as an assassin, letting the heat fall on others while still helping evil secure the crucial mission fails, especially late in the game. I could improve by more actively shaping table talk and accusations earlier, so that endgame suspicions are directed more predictably toward the wrong targets.

player_observations.Alice: Your Morgana play was subtle; you didn’t over-claim insight, which made the Merlin/Morgana distinction harder for good. You could lean a bit more into confidently pushing narratives to drag more suspicion away from Bob.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin you played cautiously and didn’t hard-clear many players, which kept you alive longer but also left your team with less direction. Your low-key style nearly kept you safe, but a bit more targeted nudging might have helped good avoid stacking evil late.
player_observations.Charlie: You tended to trust early mission compositions and didn’t strongly challenge the developing consensus, which made you seem agreeable but also somewhat passive. A bit more skepticism and vocal reasoning might help you avoid being steered by evil.
player_observations.Diana: You consistently favored ‘safe-looking’ teams and were willing to repeat players from previous missions, which is stabilizing but also exploitable by hidden evil. Adding more structured reasoning about who is cleared vs. tainted could sharpen your impact.
player_observations.Eve: You played a solid, middle-of-the-road good game, neither too loud nor too quiet, which made you hard to read and easy to keep on teams. Pushing harder on who you distrusted and why could have shifted some of the critical later-team discussions.
player_observations.Frank: As a leader on a key mission, you opted for a fairly inclusive, information-rich team, which unfortunately let evil slip in while still looking reasonable. Being a bit more suspicious of players with ambiguous histories might help you build safer late-game teams.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival you seemed genuinely conflicted about the Merlin/Morgana signals, which is good (you weren’t tunneling), but you didn’t fully weaponize your role to protect Merlin. Sharper cross-checking of who pushed or avoided Alice vs. Bob could have given you a clearer read.
player_observations.Iris: Your Mordred play stayed nicely under the radar; you avoided drawing role-based suspicion and helped keep good uncertain about where the fails came from. You could perhaps take more initiative in steering narratives, as your low profile gave you influence but not maximum control.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I timed my sabotage contributions well, staying low-profile early and helping secure the final two mission fails without drawing too much suspicion directly onto myself. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around Merlin and Percival—pushing harder to frame alternative suspects and to protect Henry’s endgame kill options.

player_observations.Alice: Played an effective Morgana by staying close to the action just enough to be seen as a plausible Merlin while not over-asserting reads, which helped muddy Grace’s perception. Could potentially have leaned a bit more into confident table-shaping to more strongly compete with Bob’s apparent accuracy.
player_observations.Bob: Very strong Merlin presence with seemingly accurate reads and cautious team selections, especially early, which forced evil to win more subtly through later mission manipulation. Might slightly benefit from occasionally seeding one or two deliberate small inaccuracies to avoid being such a clear assassination target.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and generally trustworthy, with their early mission success helping to establish a solid good baseline. Seemed to follow others’ leads rather than drive strategy, which kept them safe but limited their influence on crucial late-game decisions.
player_observations.Diana: Consistent, steady good play—participated in early successes and didn’t generate much suspicion, which made including Diana on teams feel relatively safe. Could improve by being a bit more vocal about structured logic for team picks instead of mostly going along with the developing consensus.
player_observations.Eve: Played a central role in a key fail mission (Mission 3 team) from a table-perception standpoint, which created useful ambiguity for evil even though Eve was actually good. Might strengthen future games by tracking voting patterns more aggressively and challenging suspicious team compositions earlier.
player_observations.Frank: As a leader of a failing mission, Frank’s choices added useful noise and helped create a crowded pool of suspects, especially with a 5-player team. Could benefit from clarifying their reasoning more explicitly when choosing large teams, to either build trust or better detect resistance from evil players.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, did a solid job of treating both Merlin candidates seriously, which prevented an easy lock on Bob for most of the game. Could slightly improve by cross-checking Merlin candidates’ consistency against mission outcomes more rigorously toward the endgame to better shield the real Merlin.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed low-key as the Assassin and preserved flexibility for the endgame, which is valuable when Merlin is not blatantly obvious. Could improve by more actively gathering and verbalizing read-justments so that the final assassination decision is better grounded in the table’s full information flow.
